Most of the Scottishprogramming is rather good. Documentaries like Poverty Safari presented by the rapper Loki, for example ndash something the UK BBC would never have done.And therersquos quality. The drama Guilt was as good as anything on Netflix. Scotland has a unique character that is well suited to sardonic noir.The BBC is only the latest example of Scotland potentially losing great British institutions that were supposedly threatened onlywe voted Yes. Remember Royal Bank of Scotland saying that it would up sticks after independence Well, without a trace of irony, or self-awareness, RBS has just renamed itself the National Westminster Bank, in recognition of the fact that  per cent of its business is in the South.Another pillar of the Scottish financial sector, Standard Le, also threatened to leave Scotlandthere was a Yes vote in . It has now shted pound billion in assets to Dublin.Scots have a highly-developed sense of self-deprecating humour. Just as well. Because otherwise we might get very angryndash like those French demonstrators in Yellow Vests. Wersquore used to it. Like the weather.But yoursquod think that there would be just a hint of contrition from those nominally Scottish institutions which sought so recklessly to damage Scotlandrsquos reputation and national self-confidence five years agoRBS was already effectively a London bank in , with the majority of its operations in England. The threatened departure was contrived for political purposes.The same goes for Standard Le. Without a momentrsquos reflection, it has shted a number of operations to Ireland the better to remain in the European Union.I need hardly remind readers that Scots were told that only by voting No in , could Scotland be sure of remaining in the European Union. David Nish, the boss of Standard Le said almost exactly that. Many Scots believed him. When the history of Scottish independence is written, that will be up there with the poll tax and Margaret Thatcher.The list of broken referendum promises goes on and on. ldquoAs near a federal system as possible in the UK was how the former Labour PM, Gordon Brown, described the constitutional future should Scotland reject independence. That was the substance of The Vow published by the Daily Record, in cod vellum, and signed by all three UK party leaders.Well, the powers of Holyrood have been substantially curbed in the UK Withdrawal Act. The UK Government, when it can be bothered, insists that those powers over agriculture, fisheries, environment and so on will come winging back once Boris has Got Brexit Done.Anyone who believes that hasnrsquot been listening. Scotland will be allowed to administer these s, but standards will be set by the UK the better to facilitate trade deals with countries like America. Similarly, Michael Goversquos promise that Scotland would get powers over immigration after Brexit look ridiculous now.Itrsquos enough to make you want another referendum. Nicola Sturgeon keeps saying that Indyref will happen later this year. But that is a heroic case of hope triumphing over experience, or reality itself.The joke is on us. There wonrsquot be another legal referendum now that Mr Johnson is home with an -seat majority in Westminster.It feels ashistory itself is trolling Scotland, seeing just how much humiliation Scots are prepared to take.:Boris-induced surge evokes electric shock experimentEnglish people werenrsquot so docile and biddable. When Brexiters were confronted with Project Fear, they scoffed and voted regardless for what they regarded as independence from Brussels.Scots were given an offer they couldnrsquot refuse in : a borderless independence within Europe. Unfortunately, we did refuse it. And wersquore stuck with it.And herersquos the kicker. If Scotland had voted Yes, does anyone seriously think David Cameron would have staged that referendum on Brexit

title: always-considered-political-writer-roddy-doyle-time-mortality-dublin-pubs
story: Has anyone done as much to write Dublin into the public imagination as Roddy Doyle over the last few decades  Yet he can still move around the city of his birth, the city where he has lived for more than  years, mostly uninterrupted. ldquoHaving a surname like Doyle in this country helps, he suggests when he finally joins me on the mezzanine. ldquoItrsquos the sixth most common surname, so,I say my surname nobody says, lsquoOh helliprsquoldquoI suppose at this stage in my le being bald and wearing glasses,I go out into the Dublin streets Irsquom not alone. I got the bus here today and walked through town and Irsquoll do the reverse going home. Itrsquos how I normally travel. Nobody comes near me. So, that side of it is easy to manage.Perhaps it shouldnrsquot surprise us that writers go unnoticed, but Doyle, you might think, would be a special case. Since his first novel The Commitments was published in  and certainly since it was turned into a movie a few years later, Doyle has been public property in Ireland. He won the Booker Prize for his  novel Paddy Clarke Ha Ha Ha, seen his first three books turned into movies, and has been lauded and loathed in his home country for his presentation of Dublin and Ireland in novels and on the big and small screen. The first episode of Family, the hard-hitting  TV series about domestic violence and poverty was watched by half of Irelandrsquos adult population. And they all had an opinion on it. Politicians and church leaders railed against it. There was even a death threat made against Doyle. Things have, thankfully, rarely been so heated since but he remains part of the national conversation.Hersquos good at talking. So much so that he is about to embark on a -date Conversations with Roddy Doyle tour, which is the reason Irsquom here, although wersquoll spend most of our time talking about Dublin and time and mortality and the appeal of a Dublin pub.But the tour first. Where did the idea come from  ldquoAround spring and autumn invites to festivals come in, he begins, in way of explanation. ldquoThere seems to be a huge appetite for festivals. I donrsquot really share it, Irsquove got to say. I couldnrsquot get worked up about going to hear writers talk, but people in the production company and my agency have been to events that I do, and they enjoyed them, and they thought they were good standalone things.ldquoSo, I was persuaded and not with much dficulty to go on this tour. Itrsquos  events. Itrsquos not rock n roll. There is no rider. I wonrsquot be flinging the television out of the hotel window.No karaoke then  ldquoI wonrsquot be breaking into song, no. Not yet anyway.Instead, hersquoll do a bit of talking and a bit of reading. Among writers only fellow Irishman Sebastian Barry might be better at the latter. It is a chance to size up a letime of work.ldquoI have  novels to choose from and two collections of short stories so therersquos plenty, he says. ldquoIrsquom more comfortable looking back on my old work than I used to be. I used to just run away from it when it was finished as quickly as I could and become immersed in something new. And I still try to immerse myself in something new, but I donrsquot need to deny my catalogue.Why do you think you did in the past  ldquoI didnrsquot want to wallow in it. I was afraid I might try to replicate it. Probably the best decision I ever made when I won the Booker Prize for Paddy Clarke was to make the decision never to go back there, never go back to him. I forgot about that book to the extent that I almost forgot Irsquod written it and forgot that I had been involved in The Commitments movie, for example. Itrsquos when my kids started watching it years later that I began to reclaim it.ldquoI suppose Irsquom at an age where Irsquom calmer about it. The Snapper [his second novel about an unmarried teenage pregnancy] in this country, the film particularly, is known off by heart. Itrsquos on every Christmas. Itrsquos a family occasion. I did a stage adaptation and they did a great job but, in many ways, you didnrsquot need it. The audience could have sat there and recited it to one another and just laughed.ldquoThat seemed to me a terric thing. I felt very lucky. Irsquom happy to look back on that work now.Read More: "Cant you feel the anger " David Baddiel on social media trollsItrsquos dficult to think of a Scottish equivalent to Doyle, someone whose work has been so central to the national conversation from the beginning. Irvine Welsh at a push, maybe, but it is a big push. ldquoIrsquove always considered myself a political writer, Doyle suggests. ldquoI donrsquot look around for issues. I create characters and the characters bring issues with them. Irsquove written about characters who were unemployed, characters who were pregnant outside marriage at a time when that was very signicant, characters who have been victims of violence in the home. In the last novel Smile the narrator has been abused by a Christian Brother.ldquoI could spend a considerable amount of time in radio studios or on the phone claiming some sort of expertise but beyond my writing I donrsquot. My job is trying to tell a story. I very rarely go beyond the pages of the book and start talking in a general sense. Therersquos an election on the moment and Irsquom not opening my mouth. Itrsquos a few days before the Irish election when we meet. There are posters on every lamp post. The front page of Thehas splashedon a poll that suggests surging support for Sinn Fein. Doyle wonrsquot say who he will vote for or who others should vote for. ldquoIf somebody like myself said, lsquovote for this party,rsquo it would irritate the hell out of me.That said, scratch the surface and hersquoll talk more generally about the soon-to-be-ex Taoiseach , about the crisis of homelessness in Dublin and about the cityrsquos affordability ndash or lack of it ndash for the younger generations. All parties have embraced the need for more council housing, he points out.ldquoSome of them are saying people can then buy them, which will just restart the problem ,  years down the line. Therersquos an obsession with home ownership. Itrsquos not a Dublin problem. Itrsquos an Irish problem and it may go back to the land wars in the s and the famine.Still, unlike the UK, where Brexit was a vote led by the elderly, Ireland has seen younger generations direct the arguments over same sex marriage and abortion.ldquoIt will be interesting to seethey all come out this election. It could be the breakdown of the old system and the old notion that you havenrsquot truly become an adult until you own a house, which is probably unique in Europe to Britain and Ireland.ldquoI speak as a homeowner. I wonrsquot be giving it away. My kids can do what they want with it when Irsquom not around.Doylersquos writing le began before fatherhood . Itrsquos now more than  years since Doyle, then in his late twenties, wrote The Commitments. ldquoItrsquos  years since the film, he adds. ldquoHow do you measure  years  Itrsquos hard to accept that  is  years ago."I was just thinking today, my father died six years ago. Thatrsquos one-tenth of my le effectively and it doesnrsquot feel like that at all. It feels like last year perhaps, whereas something that happened in my childhood feels like where it should be, half a century away. The way we measure time changes as we get older, which is interesting as a facet of storytelling.I want to ask him about that -year-old teacher who wrote The Commitments, when he was known as "PunkDoyle". How punk were you, Roddy  ldquoNot particularly. I liked a lot of the music. I had a pair of Doc Martens and an earring.An earring in an Irish school  ldquoI took it out for the interview. I couldnrsquot lsquofindrsquo it that morning. Wore a suit. The dress code was quite casual.ldquoI loved The Clash and the Sex Pistols. Still do. But I was never a punk. Never close to being a punk. It just seemed another kind of unorm. I was called lsquoPunkrsquo in school because of the earring and the Doc Martens. That was it, really. There were other Doyles on the staff inevitably and one of them was called Dozy, so I was better off.When he sat down to write that first book, what was he reacting against  ldquoI wasnrsquot reacting against anything really. It was much more positive than that. It was much more joyousyou like. Therersquos an anger. Therersquos an energy. There always has been, always will be. Butthere is such a thing, it was a joyous anger. It was an appreciation of where I came from, what I had, and I think teaching gave me that.ldquoI was listening to the kids around me and remembering when this place was a field because it was more rural when I was a child. That would have been Paddy Clarke. I began to realise the spirit of the place and the energy of the place was there to be used. That was what I was picking up on when I wrote The Commitments.The Commitments and all of Doylersquos novels hum with the rhythm of Dublin speech. As a reader, I guess Irsquove grown up alongside Doyle. The twentysomething I was when I fell so avidly on those Barrytown novels was in my late forties when his short story collection Bullfighting appeared with its attendant intimations of middle age and mortality.Doyle writes what he knows. ldquoTo me it feels natural. This is the material that I have now. My father was , so hersquod led a good le, been healthy, good in his head right to the day before he died. So, grief announces itself in a way it hadnrsquot before. Irsquod had friends who had died, but this was a dferent one, this was your father.He wrote a play, Two Pints, that drew on this. ldquoI think itrsquos the best thing Irsquove written in many, many ways and also I could see it as some kind of tribute to my da.His new book Love which comes out in May sts through similar themes. Itrsquos about male friendships, middle age and dying parents. Doylersquos mother died while he was writing it. ldquoItrsquos bizarre becoming an orphan at the age of . And I think from a writing point of view itrsquos interesting. Itrsquos interesting getting older, mortality, slowing down, speeding up in some ways. Time, the things it does to you. The sense of redundancy when your children grow up and they donrsquot need you. Nobody wants to get older, but it is rich material for writing.ldquoLess and less people will read it. The book clubs are overwhelmingly women and they donrsquot want to read about ageing men. Ageing men want to read about Hitler and Stalin and football. They donrsquot want to read about themselves. But nevertheless hellipThe new book is essentially about a mid-le crisis. Is that a real thing  ldquoI donrsquot know, to be honest. I donrsquot know whatrsquos the extent of the crisis, in terms of how expensive the motorbike is or how long it lasts  How do measure a crisis You havenrsquot bought a motorbike  ldquoNo, but I know people who have. Itrsquos rusting in the back garden. Irsquom nearly  now, so whatever I do it wonrsquot be mid-anything. I didnrsquot go off to explore the world. I didnrsquot go to hellip What do you call it  Burning Man. So, maybe I missed an opportunity.Love is a novel about missed opportunities. Itrsquos dark and comic and sad and takes place mostly in Dublin pubs. There are a lot of pubs in it, Roddy. ldquoAnd, actually, a fraction of a fraction of the ones that could have been chosen.What is the appeal  "Itrsquos hard to explain. Itrsquos the sense at certain times of dayof calm. The sense of it being slightly forbidden, which is great. It does good things for the self-respect. I really should be somewhere ."Therersquos a pub near here I could sit in, and I mightnrsquot talk to anybody but I amlistening to the conversation. And theyrsquore looking at the race on the telly and I feel somehow involved, even though I donrsquot have skin in the game. Somehow I know thatI said something it would be answered and then yoursquore in."You say at one point that the pub is a ldquoshy manrsquos haven. Are you that shy man ldquoCould be, yeah. I can feel at home in a pub. Depends on the pub, depends on the time of day, but, yes, I could be that shy man. I suspect a man who isnrsquot shy couldnrsquot have come up with that line.ldquoI have very close friends, men I have known since I was a child and we meet regularly. I havenrsquot been in their houses in decades. We donrsquot do that. We go to the football and we meet in a pub and we have the autopsy in a pub and itrsquos like the football is the meat in a sandwich in a way.ldquoIf I didnrsquot drink,I was warned off the alcohol orI was an alcoholic this might be a very dferent conversation, but Irsquom not. Itrsquos a good question. Would I be comfortable in a pubIrsquod done damage to myself and drinking is dangerous  I suspect I probably could be. Luckily, I donrsquot have to.Love, as he has already said, is about two ageing men. Two ageing men talking, increasingly drunkenly, about their feelings. Are we as a gender getting better at that  ldquoI think maybe. I do know there are people who, when you are talking about a problem, get it and there are others ndash and itrsquos not just men ndash who root around in their memories and say, lsquoThis happened to someone ,rsquo asit is a card game. lsquoIrsquoll top your king with an ace.rsquoHisfather, he recalls, was fostered as a child. "He was sent out of the house to a relationshouse miles and miles from where he lived. It was a huge family, he was the eldest.The pressure was on for space and money, I suspect. And He didnrsquotsee his mother for a year at least."I was trying to draw him out on it, but he was very reluctant to say that he was devastated.Very reluctant. He did say that an older cousin met him and realised he wasnrsquot happy and went to my grandmother and told her and that was the end of that, whereas I know myself,it had occurred to me, Irsquod make more of it.I would be more open about talking about it. So there are things like that that suggest we are better at talking about it, but itrsquos a huge generalisation."Your new book is called Love. Whatrsquos your definition of that word, Roddy  ldquoI donrsquot have one. Itrsquos such a vague word. I love coffee. I love my children. I love my we. I love Dublin. I love a bag of chips. And the word is perfectly accurate on all occasions. And it means entirely dferent things. So, I donrsquot really know.ldquoI wonrsquot be losing sleep trying to define love, but you have indicated that I am going to be answering that f****** question quite a lot in the next six months.We walk outside to take photographs. People walk past, look at him and walk on. Soon, he will get back on the bus to go home. He loves this city, he says. Not uncritically, but wholeheartedly.He might not be a writerhe hadnrsquot lived here, he says. Or at least hersquod be a very dferent one. Inevitably Dublin is very dferent to the city he grew up in. Itrsquos older, hersquos older, we are all older. The world moves on.ldquoIf I was somehow trying to recreate the city of my youth you could find corners, Roddy Doyle says. ldquoYou could find a few pubs that look the same. Luckily, the toilets are a good deal better. Theyrsquore lit, for example.Letrsquos run with that idea. Roddy Doyle has lit up Dublin. In his books we can see it in all its colours. Thatrsquos something, isnrsquot it  Thatrsquos worth being recognised for.Conversations with Roddy Doyle is on at the Queens Hall, Edinburgh on March . His novel Love will be published by Jonathan Cape in May.

title: abbey-strand-queens-airbnb-apartments-open-capital
story: The tenement, parts of which date back to , yesterday welcomed its first guests as "Abbey Strand Apartments at Holyrood" opened its doors after a two-year, multi-million-pound renovation.Standing opposite the Palace of Holyroodhouse and the Scottish Parliament at the foot of the Royal Mile, Abbey Strand been transformed into luxury five-star holiday lets, each with a price tag of pound a night.Abbey Strand dates to the th centuryThe building is part of The Royal Collection Trust , a department of the Royal Household and Prince Charles, RCT Chairman, has been closely involved with the project, including the choice of its "pale-pink" facade, produced using traditional methods.And as part of the renovation, the ground and first floor have been reconstructed into a Learning Centre for school groups, families and adults visiting the Palace of Holyroodhouse.:New study uncovers  descendants of family who signed Declaration of ArbroathGavin MacLennan, General Manager of the Lateral City Apartments collection, which will run the pound-per-night apartments, said: "Itrsquos fantastic to see the building re-imagined and coming to le again for a new generation of people who love Edinburgh."At Abbey Strand guests can enjoy Edinburghrsquos history, its culture and be excited about its future. These walls are steeped in history and have interesting stories to tell. Staying in these apartments will be a completely unique experience."We have been working closely with Royal Collection Trust to ensure everything is perfect, from capturing the history and heritage of the building through to the experience of the guests when they arrive. This is a special place and wersquore looking forward to sharing its stories with our guests."Interiors have been remodeledAbbey Strand has a colourful history. Inhabitants include Mary, Queen of Scotsrsquo courtiers and the Italian composer Domenico Corri and essayist Thomas De Quincy.The oldest section was part of a group of buildings connected with Holyrood Abbey around  and may have been the Abbots Mansion.In medieval times it was also an almshouse with accommodation for the poor or elderly, and later part of the hospital of St Leonard.In , the building was used by King James V as a weapons store, and when Mary, Queen of Scots moved into the Palace in , Abbey Strand was extended to provide lodgings for courtiers and ambassadors.By the s the ground floor was occupied by a brewery and a row of taverns. Part of the building was home to infamous brothel-keeper Lucky Spence, immortalised in Allan Ramsays poem Lucky Spences Last Advice, published in , about her final words, advising her "loving Lasses" how to rob and exploit patrons.In the th century, the apartments -- expanded again to house up to  families -- were a sanctuary for debtors. Sir Walter Scott considered taking refuge there after falling into financial dficulties, and author de Quincey is thought to have stayed at lodgings nearby.Mary Queen Of Scots, asplayed bySaoirse Ronan in a recent fim.In the s the skeleton of a child was discovered in a wall after a shoemaker tried to make an opening for a new window.:He beat the English, now Wallace faces his biggest challengehellip timeBy , Abbey Strand housed a restaurant, a confectioners, a tavern and a spirits merchant, before ious restoration projects in the th century aimed to improve living conditions.The new apartments feature historic fireplaces and original stone walls, blended together with "all the essentials of luxury st century living" and "quirky windows".

title: unspun-political-diary
story: AMATEUR psychologists have been having a field day with the latest issue of Holyrood magazine and its interview with Wendy Chamberlain. The newbie LibDem MP for North East Fe revealed her earliest memory was being caught stealing a toy from playgroup. ldquoWhen we came to collect our stuff at the end of the week, I helped myself, she confessed. She later joined the police. No massive guilt there then.Egg headMS Chamberlain also disclosed she considers Willie Rennie her ldquowork husband, while her real husband is a member of the SNP. But most eye-catching was her guiltiest pleasure. ldquoEating Creme Eggs whole, she declared. Last week she found three boxes of the sickly blobs in a cupboard at home. ldquoMy husband knows me so well, she said. But which one Highland messNAT Richard Lyle raised eyebrows when he tried to jump into Holyrood questions about the Highlands  Islands, as his Bellshill seat boasts neither. Deputy PO Christine Grahame smelled a rat. ldquoMr Lyle, I have to caution you. If I do not hear lsquoHighlands and Islandsrsquo in your first breath, you are stopping in your tracks. He then made a classic toady point about UK immigration plans hurting ldquothe tourism industry in Scotland - and the Highlands and Islands Ms Grahame narrowed her eyes. ldquoAh, the work of a pro, Mr Lyle.Silicon chapsWITH his gt for almost finding the right word for the right occasion, Mr Lyle also features in many a Holyrood malapropism. Quizzing Queensferry Crossing bosses about build-ups on the bridge in freezing weather recently, he solemnly opined about ldquoice accreditation on the bridge. But even better was the mental image created by the Scottish Greens this week in a press release referring to Scotlandrsquos ill-fated computer sector as ldquoSilicone Glen. Wersquove never met him, or his implants, but wersquore sure hersquos a lovely chap.Crystal ballsIN the first of short series on the prophetic visions of Jackson Carlaw, we bring you this little forecast from November . After meeting vampiric new Tory leader Michael Howard, JC reported he had ldquoexuded charm and elan.. A man with both style and passion who struck me as both a winner and a potential prime minister. As for the Toriesrsquo opponents  ldquoWith Michael Howard we are ready to take the fight to them and in time we will win. He lasted two years.Matt finishTOUGH times for Glasgow councillor Matt Kerrrsquos underdog fight to be deputy leader of Scottish Labour. He recently tweeted out a campaign picture bearing the slogan ldquoIrsquove voted Matt Kerr. He then added gratuitously ldquoIrsquove voted Matt Kerr for Deputy leader of Scottish Labour above it. At which point, Twiiter groaned en masse: ldquoI should hope so, Matt!Political networkWHAT is going on with Scotlandrsquos newest, and most mysterious, party  Clues from the Electoral Commission suggest the fledgling Independent Scotland Party, founders as yet unknown, has already changed its name to the Independence for Scotland Party. The logonow bears the letters ISP. But as any fule kno, this is short for Internet Service Provider. Whether the quixotic Independence for Scotland Party proves as unpopular as every other ISP remains to be seen.

title: set-citizens-assembly-thrash-future-council-services-says-expert
story: Professor Richard Kerley said the forum could discuss what councils should deliver and how such services should be paid for.It comes just days after the pound billion Scottish Budget passed its first stage at Holyrood following a deal between the minority SNP administration and the Greens.The spending plans include pound million of further funding for local government, with the Government saying this takes its total additional support for councils to poundm.However, local authorities argue they are struggling after years of cuts and rising demand. They warn many areas are now at ldquocrisis point.In an interview to be published in tomorrowrsquos Herald on Sunday, Mr Kerley said a wide-ranging review could help shape a sustainable future for local government.He said: ldquoI think it would be helpful to have another review of what we expect local government to do, and how we expect local government to do it.ldquoWhat is appropriate to charge for and not charge for  Because that makes a signicantdference in terms of the usage of facilities and services.He added: ldquoI donrsquot think it can be done by just saying, lsquoOkay, wersquoll increase this tax or that tax, or stop doing thatrsquo.The academic said the review could examine what services Scots expect councils to deliver, ldquoand how we might raise some of the money to do that, some of which could be raised locally, some of which would be raised through general taxation as it is now.He said it could involve representatives from all of Scotlandrsquos councils and the government ldquoand citizens as well.Mr Kerley, professor of management at Queen Margaret University, said: ldquoWersquove seen experiments in terms of the Citizens Assembly.You could incorporate something like that ndash plus people who have a particular interest.He said the current Citizensrsquo Assembly of Scotland, which brings together more than  people randomly recruited from across the country to discuss key issues facing it, has shown such an exercise is ldquoperfectly possible.In the years since devolution, there have been a number of reviews set up to consider local taxation.In , the Local Government Finance Review Committee proposed a ldquoradical alternative to council tax. Itrecommended a ldquonew progressive Local Property Tax... based on the capital value of inidual properties.Around a decade later, the Commission on Local Tax Reform recommended a programme of changes, including multiple forms of tax and a review of central grants.The Barclay Review into business rates in  also examined the role of local authorities.Mr Kerley said it is ldquoundisputed the proportion of central government spend that has gone to support local government over the past X years has been decreasing gradually compared to other areas of spend.It comes as Scotlandrsquos council leaders yesterday expressed disappointment that the agreed Budget deal only makes good the underfunding of new and existing commitments required by the Scottish Government and does nothing to address inflationary or demand pressures.It also fails to make any restoration of the signicant cuts to Local Government core funding in previous years.Leaders agreed that, as such, the settlement represents a  per cent or poundmillion cut in real terms in revenue funding for Local Government.Council Leaders instructed the Convention of Scottish LocalAuthorities to continue to lobby strongly for the additional % funding for inflationary pressures and % for restoration of previous funding cuts and for restoration of the poundm cut to the capital allocation.Mr Kerley said: ldquoThere clearly comes a point where councils have to say, as they have been saying for years, some of them, lsquowe canrsquot keep trimming a bit off here and a bit off there, and turning the lights off earlierrsquo and stuff like that.ldquoIn the longer term, you canrsquot provide for increased public services without increasing the flow of money into that ndash whether thatrsquos through taxation or charging, and wersquove generally resisted charging of ious kinds, though everywhere you look where councils are enabled to charge they are increasing the charges they are putting on things.ldquoAnd they are testing out, with for example musical tuition, whether they can charge for that. I think thatrsquos going to be an interesting test of legal commitment and legal powers and legal authority when it ndash as I think it will ndash goes into court in some shape or form.Mr Kerley said local authorities charging for services has always been ldquoa bit of a tangle, adding: ldquoWe charge for some things and we donrsquot charge for others. Some of them are statutorily protected in terms of charging. You canrsquot charge for lending library books,but you can charge for the lateof library books.ldquoYou charge for theatres, you charge for going into a swimming pool ndash how much you charge is a matter of what you need to raise and what you think people will pay.He said reforming council tax is ldquoone possibility, but added the ldquobig challenge for any government is the notion that you can, through a local property tax and indeed through income tax, make all of this additional money up through just affecting wealthy people or rich people...[it] just doesnrsquot hold.Councils argue funding provided by the Scottish Government is often ringfenced, funnelling extra cash directly into areas chosen by ministers, such as the expansion of free childcare.But Mr Kerley said the degree of ring-fencing ldquois considerably less than it was  or  years ago.He said: ldquoItrsquos reduced, but itrsquos now creeping back up again ndash I think most obviously with nursery education, because the huge commitment to, in a sense double, the amount of nursery education available for three and fouryear-olds meant councils had to create often purpose-built facilities or improve the ones they had, increase staffing and so on. The nature of what councils do has crept up and crept up and crept up over time.

title: queen-urged-cull-deer-balmoral
story: The number of red deer at the monarchrsquos Scottish retreat culled over the last  years has fallen by  per cent. Deer numbers on the estate, part of Caenlochan Glen, increased by % between  and  from , to ,.The Scottish Government says deer population control in Scotland is a major issue, because the animals destroy forests that are needed in the fight against climate change, as are peatlandrsquos, which the deer can disturb.They are also estimated to cause , road accidents every year in Scotland. Earlier this year, a report ordered by the Scottish Government recommended thousands more deer be culled annually across the country to address the issue.Dave Morris, former director of Ramblers Scotland, the countryrsquos association representing hillwalkers, said: ldquoWe have major problems in Scotland with too many deer and the effect itrsquos having on the natural habitat.ldquoI think Caenlochan is the worst area for deer in Scotland and Balmoral is part of the problem.ldquoItrsquos time the Royal Family,they are serious about climate change, start reducing numbers of deer.Robbie Kernahan, director at Scottish Natural Heritage said: ldquoThe estates in the South Grampian and Caenlochan area, including Balmoral, have been working with SNH to reduce deer numbers.A SNH spokesman added: ldquoOur recent Deer Progress Report showed that while challenges remain, signicant progress has been made by landowners and managers.ldquoSNH leads a programme of work to promote sustainable deer management across Scotland, recognising the essential role it needs to play to help address climate change and bioersity loss.ldquoResearch shows deer numbers increased in Scotland from  to , but numbers have since stabilised because of increased culling, which is sometimes necessary to ensure healthy deer populations, reduce road traffic accidents and prevent signicant damage to our agriculture, forestry and nature.A Balmoral source said: ldquoRed deer are an iconic addition to Balmoral but there can be a clear conflict between deer culling and ensuring local forests are maintained around the estate.ldquoThe estate is doing itrsquos very best to ensure a balance is maintained and is working with relevant authorities to ensure this is achieved.A recent report has said up to one million wild deer, nearly double previous estimates, could be roaming the country, damaging the landscape and hampering environmental efforts.The findings, published by the Deer Working Group, is urging Scottish ministers to crack down on uncooperative Highland estates that refuse to control deer numbers to protect their lucrative hunting market, by using legal powers to enforce culls.But landowners have criticised the recommendations, saying the report comes in sharp contrast to similar research by Scottish Natural Heritage published just two months earlier.The body that represents rural businesses and landowners, Scottish Land and Estates , also insisted conflicting evidence on the future of deer management in Scotland should not overshadow the recent progress achieved.It maintained the issue was not about overall deer numbers but about their impact on local areas.Sarah-Jane Laing, chief executive of the SLE, said: ldquoSubstantial progress has been made in the operation of deer management groups over the past five years, with the sector demonstrating its ability to respond and adapt to new challenges and manage deer in a way that is sustainable and safeguards public interests."Some deer estates in areas such as Glen Artney and Strathtay, Perthshire, have red deer densities above  per square kilometre, while numerous parts of Inverness-shire, the Cairngorms, Deeside and Angus have between  and  per square kilometre. The report endorses SNHrsquos identication of the need for signicant changes in deer management as an important issue in climate crisis mitigation measures, and recommends that it is addressed as a priority. Conservationists argue that red deer, who often roam in vast herds, prevent woodland and shrubs from naturally regenerating.Ms Laing added: ldquoThe right density is also dependent on pasture availability rather than a strict number applicable across every region.

title: herald-diary-large-inside-glasgows-anarchic-school-art
story: Sometimes the tools required are more specic. For example, I happen to be walking through a certain studentrsquos workspace when I spot a pair of wind-up  teeth. The comedy kind, much favoured by agents of anarchy such as Dennis the Menace and the Bash Street Kids. The teeth havenrsquot been sneaked into the room for a giggle. Theyrsquore a vital part of the learning process. Though whatrsquos being learned here is how to be windswept and interesting.Irsquom on a tour of Glasgow School of Art, a place that is best described as a botanic garden for the hot-housing of bohemian types. If therersquos a box lying around some place, these guys want to think outside of it. On a matter of principle.In that context the chattering plastic teeth make a lot of sense. They are art. Or are waiting to become art. When your uninspired layman spots a cheap and tacky toy from a joke shop, he thinks to himself: ldquoOh, look. A cheap and tacky toy from a joke shop. But when an artist spots that self-same trinket, he or she starts to count the possibilities. And there are many. Those rattling teeth become a metaphor for the rictus grin of our dying society. Or perhaps they are tragically symbolic of the fake, plastic, disposable lives we are all forced to endure under the yoke of st century capitalism. So the plastic teeth are not just plastic teeth. They are a textbook, a laptop and a bunch of notepads, all rolled into one.Get creativeIt isnrsquot only the set of joke shop chompers that prove to be out of the ordinary on my tour of the Art School. Therersquos also some sort of metal, car-like machine that has been welded together from what seems to be rusty fragments of scrap iron. Elsewhere, a student has hung up a painted sign on which is scrawled the statement: lsquoMy worldrsquos on fire. How about yours rsquoPainted images paper the walls. Some are pretty striking.One image is a close-up view of flayed flesh. The kind of thing I imagine Hannibal Lecter might sketch in his spare time, in between snacking on human hotpot.Therersquos plenty more way-out and wacky work on display. Which is all to the good, as far as Irsquom concerned. If you canrsquot breach boundaries and tickle taboos when yoursquore a young, ambitious artist, when  can you do so  I actually feel very privileged to be strolling through the open minds of some seriously creative students. To grab a ringside seat as they blossom into badass. The Glasgow School of Art has a legendary alumni, after all. Robbie Coltrane. Muriel Gray. Fran Healy. Peter Capaldi. Some of them, just to be perverse, even become artists. My guides for the tour are Martha Stefani-Bose and Maja Tacchi, both in their third year at Glasgow School of Art, where they are also student ambassadors. Each Friday they take a group of prospective students round campus, to show them the delights contained within these walls of wit and way-out wonder. Members of the public arenrsquot invited on these guided tours, though Irsquove managed to sneak along using my Access All Areas Scotland Pass. Actually, I donrsquot really have such a pass. Irsquom just a pushy journo who manages to go places Irsquom not invited. One of the genuine would-be students on the tour is Sandra McWilliams, who was previously a successful accountant. She even had her own business for  years, but ultimately found it less than fulfilling. So she decided to get creative with her le.ldquoMy husband said to me, why donrsquot you seeyou can do something with art, she explains. ldquoSo I went to Clyde College to seethere was anything they could offer.Sandra was already adept at embroidery, crochet and knitting, which allowed her to be accepted for an HND in textiles. Now she wants to take the next step in her creative journey and is hoping to be offered a place at Glasgow School of Art, starting next year. ldquoMy eldest daughter came here to do a media course, she says. ldquoAnd I felt it was such a lovely community. I was always at home when I visited. I thought it was such a small and intimate setting.The tour has changed Sandrarsquos opinion, regarding the size of the school. ldquoItrsquos much bigger than I thought, she marvels. ldquoIt really is quite a layout.Ping pong tableIt is, indeed. People with only a passing knowledge of the school probably assume itrsquos essentially the ill-fated Mackintosh building, with a few minor buildings surrounding it. Not so.The Reid Building, for instance, which was completed in  and stands opposite the Mackintosh, is where our tour begins. It is a large, multi-floored, modernistic space, open plan and awash with light. Various disciplines are studied here, including textiles and printing. In many ways it could be any further education building. It has a canteen, rows of desks, computers. There are a few more unusual elements, however. Looms for the textile students to work on. And a print room that contains numerous shelves of small metal blocks with raised letters. Such things were once used by typesetters in newspaper offices, before digital technology replaced them. It seems that this archaic way of forming words still retains its appeal with the creatives of tomorrow.Painting and fine art is studied in a building that was formerly Stow College. Although this is the place for creativity with few boundariesitrsquos actually a rather brutalist environment. The corridors, grim and grey-walled, have the sort of chill feel that would be familiar to anyone who has visited an ancient swimming baths. At a push, I could be strolling down an endless passageway in KGB headquarters, circa  something-or-other, waiting nervously for a bullet from behind to finish me off. But then I peek into the artistsrsquo studios, and Irsquom hypnotised by a technicolour trance of anarchy turned into artice.No hierarchyI also visit the school of architecture, where everything is symmetrical, systematic and very well organised, as you would expect. Therersquos also a ping pong table, which you would not expect.Of course our group doesnrsquot get to visit the Mackintosh building, which was almost destroyed by fires in  and . An extensive restoration programme is still being attempted, and the entire edice is cloaked in a porcupine like framework of scaffolding. Itrsquos almost impossible to see what lurks beneath.ldquoThere could be a giant inflatable bouncy castle under there, for all anyone knows, I say to one of the guides, Martha Stefani-Bose, who was brought up in the west end of Glasgow and is studying painting and printmaking. ldquoNow that would be an artistic statement, she says drily.On a more serious note she adds: ldquoEveryone is mourning the loss of that amazing building. Obviously it was a work of art itself. But space-wise wersquore actually doing fine. It doesnrsquot seem cramped at all, and the new arrangements allow us to work even closer together, which really helps with the collaborative process.This collaborative process is one of the key selling points of Glasgow School of Art. ldquoTherersquos no hierarchy between disciplines, says Maja Tacchi, who is from Bristol and studies architecture.ldquoItrsquos an incredibly unique environment and wersquore lucky to be here. People from all dferent courses pull together and use their dferent areas of expertise to create new and interesting work. The art school really is a community of like-minded souls. It doesnrsquot matter what year yoursquore in, how old you are, where yoursquore from, or what yoursquore studying. Wersquore all one big family.

title: fidelma-cook-coronavirus-shows-veneer-civilisation-thin
story: Twenty-nine people were killed,  seriously wounded and , lightly so, mainly from falling glass, as two thirds of the cityrsquos windows were shattered.Situated just three kilometres from the city centre and next door to a large suburban area, the factory blast affected almost , homes and completely destroyed ,.The residents were put up in a mixture of private housing, authority flats and hastily collected mobile homes. Many had only the clothes they stood up in and limited insurance.It happened more than five years before I came here but what happened in the aftermath was what was seared in the minds of the locals and used as a warning for those of us coming to remote country houses.At first it was just a handful of strangers wandering around but then, odd packed cars were seen in pulling-in places or nudged into a forest road.Chasseurs reported small white vans in forest clearings asdeliberately hidden and small bands of people aimlessly walking the roads and not with the steel-eyed commitment of the weekend walker.A few fights were reported and finally the police took an interest, uncovering unreported burglaries and thefts in and outside the many villages this rich, fruit-growing area supports.The lsquocriminalsrsquo were those whose houses no longer existed after the explosion or those who had found no further shelter. So as all city dwellers do ndash as we know from every apocalyptic film ndash they drove or walked into the country, eventually settling on La Lomagne.The permanently shuttered houses and swimming pools gave the clue that here were many holiday homes used for a handful of weeks in the summer checked on maybe once in the winter months. Perfect.:Coronavirus: patient in England caught the virus within the UK, confirm health officialsSome simply moved in for a while, using a house as a base and place to sleep. Others ndash the majority ndash stripped the houses of everything, right down to the last tea-spoon, even the kitchen sink.After all,they were rich enough to have a second home and a pool then it wouldnrsquot really hurt them went the logic.They were the ones rebuilding their homes without cash or pay-outs and out here they had found the Ikea of their dreams with no checkout till.A few who wanted more, started to approach farms to raid outdoor freezers or move anything portable from the machines stored in the barns. Farmers welding shotguns warned off most.I think of that story whenever I watch looting on the news, or therersquos a hint of food rationing and one sees the emptied supermarket aisles cleared by the mindless and the greedy.I think of it watching and reading the daily, almost casual, racism and violence on tube and bus think of it watching the Chinese being shunned and insulted all over the globe as inidually responsible for the coronavirus.And each time Irsquom shocked anew at how little it takes to scrape that veneer of civilisation off even the best of us. How little for fear and powerlessness to undo whatever carapace wersquove created and how quickly the politics of envy come into play.In France three people have died at time of writing of Covid- and dozens of others identied. If anything, a protocol of a kind is already in place.For we have a flu epidemic here ndash  people are estimated to have died since last October. But that is more acceptable for it has a known pathway and inoculations are on offer to all.Coronavirus is the unknown that strikes not just the already compromised and the elderly but, it seems, young men in particular.While our TV and papers have been pretty restrained, we have seen the scenes in Italy and, of course, China with its sealed off small towns and villages and one sees the enormity of what could happen.I have no doubt that in a deteriorating situation my farming neighbours would take up gun and barricades to keep all out and in.And no doubt too that, as history shows, the city dwellers barely an hour away, would seek the purity of our air and the remoteness of our houses, far from crowds and contamination.Should the two meet...But then I shake myself for having such melodramatic thoughts and remind myself that although it may often seem like it, wersquore not living in a dystopian world and evenwe were, the good guys always win in the end, donrsquot they Perhaps not, for they havenrsquot done much winning the last few years and maybe such thoughts are actually sound and wise. Always have a plan B.Actually, I no longer have a plan B. With my compromised lungs Irsquod be a goner from the start. In that event the army of dispossessed from Toulouse can feel free to make merry with my house and land for as long as they can.I would hope to retain my thin veneer until the end. But who knows in these situations  Bonne chance mes amis.

title: rab-mcneil-storm-teabag-woke-stir-pot
story: Thatrsquos what happened when the makers of Yorkshire Tea ndash motto, ldquoLetrsquos have a proper brew ndash got into a proper brouhaha after Tory Chancellor Rishi Sunak posted a tweet and accompanying pic of himself making ldquoa good Yorkshire brew for his Budget team colleagues.Although the tweet was just a harmless quickie, and nothing to do with the company, the usual top intellectuals on Twitter called for the teabags to be ldquocancelled and for the company to be boycotted. It was utterly nuts. But the best thing about it was how calmly and rationally Yorkshire Tea reacted on Twitter.I donrsquot do Twitter because itrsquos full of fatheads. And itrsquos an absolute minefield for offence, uber-sensitivity, inflated self-importance and saying the wrong thing. Hey, it sounds just like a newspaper column!A lot of PR folk, notably those on woke extremist police forces up and down the country, are making a right bags of things on Twitter, with people stealing the wheels off their patrol cars as they sit in the office tweeting about how ldquoprogressive they are.But Yorkshire Tea got it right. After initially being stunned at the accusations of guilt by vanishingly distant association, they tried to explain that Mr Sunakrsquos tweet was nothing to do with them and that they would never ldquointentionally stick ourselves in a Twitter storm, particularly late in the day when it was ldquonearly hometime.They also pointed out that Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn had posed similarly with their teabags in . To no avail.The increasingly deranged cyber-bullies still piled on, screaming ldquoshame on you and calling for the company to be destroyed.Baffled, the tea jennies tried to understand what was happening, and tweeted: ldquoWersquove spent the last three days answering furious accusations and boycott calls. For some, our tea just being drunk by someone they donrsquot like means itrsquos forever tainted hellipAnd: ldquoItrsquos been pretty shocking to see the determination some have had to drag us into a political mud-fight. But itrsquos been lovely to see others speak up for us hellipThat is indeed what happened, and itrsquos the beauty of Twitter that decent ratepayers can also have their say and fight back against the bullies.Even when one of the latter still went shrilly on, the company advised: ldquoSue, yoursquore shouting at tea. Please do look after yourself and try to be kind to others.Of course, you canrsquot talk any sense into such folk. The golden rule when dealing with the woke is: Never apologise, never explain. Itrsquos never enough.The aforementioned Sue went on shrieking, until Yorkshire Tea pleaded: ldquoFrom one human being to another, would [it] be OK for you to stop now  And, in so doing, it won the sympathy of everyone with an ounce of common sense.But you do wonder about what is going on inside the heads of the Sues and suchlike, whose purpose in le seems to be to persecute.There must be a shred of decency in there somewhere and, like the Spanish Inquisition, Stalinrsquos Cheka and the witch-burners of old, they must have convinced themselves that they have right on their side.But their perspective has become skewed. In the guise of liberalism they are bringing, as Orwell predicted, totalitarianism. However, it was always a weakness in Orwellrsquos writings that he could never foresee the crucial role that teabags would play in the fight for liberty.Right, time to put the kettle on.++++I GET severely discombobulated when I read about top civil servants, Treasury advisers and even Tory MPs saying they listen to hard rock. Itrsquos not natural.Hard rock is for people with long hair and tight trousers, like me back in the days when I was full of hope. True, my hair is shorter and my trousers baggier now, but Irsquom still a free spirit fighting the Man. These other people: they are the Man.The latest Establishment figure revealed to love rock is David Frost, , Boris Johnsonrsquos Europe adviser. Previously, he spent  years in the Foreign  Commonwealth Office. In , he was made a Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George. Hersquos pictured in a suit and tie.And yet he says hersquos a fan of Motorhead and Led Zeppelin. Itrsquos disgraceful for a man in such a position. Could you imagine Sir Humphrey Appleby or Sir Harold Macmillan banging their heads rhythmically to Rush Call me prejudiced, but I believe record store owners should have told Mr Frost: ldquoIrsquom sorry, sir, but this isnrsquot for the likes of you. Try up the road, where theyrsquove got some Mantovani and Brahms.++++LIKE many sad outcasts, I was delighted to read about the cast of Friends reuniting for a one-off show. And my happiness could barely be contained when I read they were being paid between .M and .M to appear.Itrsquos wonderful that artists are rewarded adequately for their hard work. Irsquom a big fan of the show, eventhe charactersrsquo flat arrangements never made realistic sense. At least two of the buddies were well-paid professionals.Itrsquos the same with that show about top physicists sharing a flat. They get on each otherrsquos wicks, but obviously thatrsquos preferable to buying a place of your own with your fat salary.Oddly enough, American sitcoms used to present the opposite scenario, with binmen and sales assistants living in huge detached houses: showcasing the American Way.Still, we could all identy with the nice young people in Friends. The show is still a top pick among young persons on yon Netflix, who envy the charactersrsquo cosy togetherness. The fact that the actors were paid M an episode provides an added warm glow.++++DONALD Trump doesnrsquot eat healthily like Scottish people do. The US president is famously carnivorous, loving well-done steaks, burgers and meatloaf. If undertaking a state visit to Greggs, itrsquos unlikely hersquod try the famous vegan sausage roll.A White House source told CNN prior to a trip to India this week: ldquoI have never seen him eat a vegetable.That made the Indian trip problematic, since his host, Prime Minister Narendra Modi, like most of the country, is ardently vegetarian. Monsieur Modi tried to interest the animal-masticating loon in veggie stuff, hiring a top chef to cook special samosas with, er, broccoli in them. Donald didnrsquot bite.His schtick seems to have been to attend the state dinners, eat nothing, then waddle rapidly back to his hotel, where a private chef expertly singed a steak for him.Earlier this week, the Trumplingrsquos former physician revealed how he used to smuggle caullower into the presidentrsquos mashed potato. Nae luck. Still, there is hope. Most people naturally dislike vegetables when children but soon grow out of it. And Mr Trump is still only .Read more: Politicians showing an assertive personality  Well, bully for them

title: kevin-mckenna-britain-unequal-society-designed-unequal-society
story: Instead, each group of schools in a town or district would be under the control of a consortium backed by private investment and hedge-fund speculators. All education would be fee-paying, of course, with the most successful schools free to charge exorbitantly for their services.School departments might be sponsored by firms specialising in the appropriate disciplines. Thus, the science department with its partners Evonik, Pfizer and Biogen would be pleased to offer a suite of subjects tailored to meet the demands of a changing world. Maths would be brought to you by Tesla Inc and foreign languages would be the preserve of international airlines and holiday firms. English could be sponsored by Penguin, Harper Collins or Bloomsbury. Obviously, these firms would expect teachers to ensure their contracted authors featured heavily in their reading lists.Further down the scale, local firms might be invited to tender for subjects in those schools unable to compete financially with the elite FTSE establishments. These would be solid enough performers and might get your child into a half-decent polytechnic and a career as an army specialist.As well as league tables for exam results there would be something similar for teachers. This would operate like the draft system for US gridiron stars. Top schools would be prepared to pay huge salaries for teachers who can spin an A from a C- with the densest of materials.:Opinion Matrix: Power battles and realities of societyIn terms of discipline, parents would be expected to sign a sort of educational pre-nup. This would effectively permit a school to discipline a child as they saw fit and indemny teachers in the event of any physical or mental damage sustained by the child.As with all pure market-driven industries the dross would be quietly discarded. Children whose parents were unable to afford even the most basic fees would be taken to educational lsquofarmsrsquo where they would be given basic instruction on physical fitness and mechanical and household maintenance. Each year in these places there would be a Hunger Games type of competition where the prize could be a free education at one of the top schools. Those firms with an authentic sense of social mission at their core would bestow scholarships for the children of factory workers with long and unblemished service records.The overall effect achieved by such a system would be to ensure that power and wealth was retained within tight clusters of the right sort. Sounds ridiculous Well, in effect, itrsquos how Britainrsquos independent and fee-paying school system works. The essential alchemy at the heart of these places has little to do with achieving academic excellence and instilling lofty values. Bright pupils excelling at a fee-paying school would also have done so at a state establishment.Letrsquos be honest here their main attraction lies in masking the intellectual weaknesses of the less able offspring of rich families, thus sparing them having to work with common people who donrsquot just wear overalls for fishing. It also explains many of the catastrophic events in British military history some decisions taken in the run-up to the banking crisis and the tenure of the Bush family and Donald Trump in the White House.The results of a survey published this week found that more than a third of Edinburgh residents felt that a childrsquos social class had a material effect on their academic school performances. This compared with just % in Glasgow. The numbers are hardly surprising when you factor in how many children attend fee-paying schools in Edinburgh: currently around one in five and the highest percentage of such in the UK.:Herald Society heroes honoured for their work helping othersIrsquom not entirely sure that this suggests Edinburgh people are more class-conscious than in Glasgow or somehow more snobbish in their attitudes. Itrsquos simply confirmation of what most of us probably already knew: thatyou want to gain influence and wealth in modern Britain it helps greatlyyou attended one of these schools. It would be instructiveMy Tutor, the online tutoring service which conducted the survey, undertook also to ask people to what extent they felt that a childrsquos natural ability affected academic performance. Perhaps this is too dficult to measure.It certainly seems beyond the wit of any British or Scottish Government to attempt to do so. As things stand we assume that children born into challenging social circumstances must be of low academic ability. We judge them purely on exam results and fail to factor in the daily challenges of health inequality and multi-deprivation. We know that none can afford private tuition, the favourite means by which affluent but academically unremarkable children can tilt the playing field. The failure of British society to find more imaginative ways of unlocking the potential of poor children must cost this country billions every year in health and social security spending and crime prevention.Perhaps then they could borrow on the notion of pure, market-driven schools and customise them to meet the needs of the many rather than the few. Irsquod grant major global firms as well as local companies a suite of incentives to provide direct funding of local authority schools in our most disadvantaged neighbourhoods. They would have no influence on educational policy. As part of the deal they would also provide employment opportunities for pupils in these schools.Funding could range from meeting the salaries of extra teachers providing resource materials and paying for overseas trips. They would meet the cost of tutors for bright children and grant them meaningful internships, currently the exclusive preserve of affluent pupils whose parents have good professional connections.Boris Johnson talked about a process of ldquolevelling up to address regional inequalities in British society. I expect that to go the same way as Margaret Thatcherrsquos promise to bestow Franciscan kindness in . The SNP Government has the power to make this a reality all that is required to make it happen is the courage to try something dferent.

title: storm-jorge-scotland-set-fourth-weekend-severe-weather
story: This monthrsquos third named storm is bringing rain, gales and snow, prompting weather warnings stretching from Cornwall to the north of Scotland and across to Northern Ireland.People in Pontypridd, which was also flooded two weeks ago, and the Ely area of Cardf, were advised to remain indoors amid warnings of further rising water levels and gusts of up to mph.Cardf Council said emergency teams worked through the night on flood defences, road closures and clearing debris to limit the damage from torrential rains as its roads team answered around  incidents.:Storm Jorge: Scotland warned to brace for weather chaosMore than  homes and a similar number of businesses have been hit in Wales, accounting for around a quarter of affected properties in the UK.England has had more than % of its average February rainfall, according to the Environment Agency, with some areas getting a monthrsquos worth in  hours.There were six yellow weather warnings for rain, wind and snow in force across the country on Saturday morning, stretching from Cornwall to the north of Scotland and across to Northern Ireland.The rain warning was lted before midday as showers eased but alerts remained in place for gales and the potential for power cuts, transport delays and large waves for coastal communities.The wind warnings last until am on Sunday across much of England and Wales and until pm the same day across Northern Ireland, southern Scotland, and northern England.Persistent snowfall was forecast over higher parts of Scotland, with up to cm predicted in some places, with warnings in place until noon on Monday, the Met Office said.A total of  flood warnings were in place across England and Wales, mostly in the South West and along the English-Welsh border, and in Yorkshire, while a further  ldquoflooding is possible alerts are also in force.Have #SaturdayAfternoon plans  Bright for many but very windy. Some #snow showers too, especially across the northStay #WeatherAware ## pic VnVmOOEAOmdash Met OfficeFebruary , The wind-chill factor will make temperatures feel close to freezing, said the Met Office.Heavy rain which started with Storm Ciara continued with Storm Dennis and now Jorge has contributed to record river levels which have seen safety teams put in ldquoHerculean efforts to erect flood defences.Towns including Ironbridge and Bewdley along the River Severn in the West Midlands, and West Cowick and Lidgate in East Yorkshire, along the River Aire, are among the worst-hit areas in England.The Environment Agency said , staff per day have worked on flood defences and pumps, clearing debris and repairing damaged defences, erecting . miles of barriers.The body warned the country needs to brace itself for ldquomore frequent periods of extreme weather like this because of climate change.

title: us-leave-afghanistan-14-months-peace-deal
story: Under the agreement, Washington would draw its forces down to , from , in the next three to four months, with the remainder withdrawing in  months.The complete pullout would depend on the Taliban meeting commitments to prevent terrorism.President George W Bush ordered the US-led invasion of Afghanistan in response to the September  attacks in . Some US troops currently serving there had not been born when the World Trade Centre was attacked.It only took a few months to topple the Taliban and send Osama bin Laden and top al Qaida militants scrambling across the border into Pakistan, but the war dragged on for years as the US tried to establish a stable, ing state in one of the least developed countries in the world.:Taliban welcomes partial US withdrawal from AfghanistanThe Taliban regrouped and currently hold sway over half the country.The US spent more than  billion dollars, and on all sides the war cost tens of thousands of lives.US secretary of state Mike Pompeo attended the ceremony in Qatar, where the Taliban have a political office, but did not sign the agreement. It was signed by US peace envoy Zalmay Khalilzad and Taliban leader Mullah Abdul Ghani Baradar.The Taliban harboured bin Laden and his al Qaida network as they plotted, and then celebrated, the hijackings of four airliners that were crashed into lower Manhattan, the Pentagon and a field in western Pennsylvania, killing almost , people.Mr Pompeo had privately told a conference of US ambassadors at the State Department this week that he was going only because President Donald Trump had insisted on his participation, according to two people present.Dozens of Taliban members had earlier held a small victory march in Qatar in which they waved the militant grouprsquos white flags, according to a video shared on Taliban websites.ldquoToday is the day of victory, which has come with the help of Allah, said Abbas Stanikzai, one of the Talibanrsquos lead negotiators, who joined the march.Mr Trump has repeatedly promised to get the US out of its ldquoendless wars in the Middle East, and the withdrawal of troops could provide a boost as he seeks re-election in a nation weary of involvement in distant conflicts.:Afghanistan and the war without endUnder the agreement, the Taliban promise not to let extremists use the country as a staging ground for attacking the US or its allies, but officials is Washington are reluctant to trust the Taliban to fulfil their obligations.The prospects for Afghanistanrsquos future are uncertain. The agreement sets the stage for peace talks involving Afghan factions, which are likely to be complicated.Under the agreement, , Taliban are to be released from Afghan-run jails, but it is not knownthe Afghan government will do that.There are also questions about whether Taliban fighters loyal to ious warlords will be willing to disarm.It is also not clear what will become of gains made in womenrsquos rights since the toppling of the Taliban, which had repressed women and girls under a strict brand of Sharia law.Womenrsquos rights in Afghanistan had been a top concern of both the Bush and Obama administrations, but it remains a deeply conservative country, with women still struggling for basic rights.Welcoming the deal, the Foreign Office in London said: ldquoThanks to the efforts of UK and coalition forces, Afghanistan is no longer a safe haven for international terrorists and Britainrsquos streets are safer.ldquoBut all sides recognise that only a political solution can ensure stability and build a lasting peace in Afghanistan.Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said: ldquoThese agreements mark a signicant moment in the pursuit of peace in Afghanistan.ldquoThe current reduction in violence is welcome and I hope it will be maintained, but meaningful negotiations between the Afghan leadership and the Taliban are the real prize and I hope this opportunity will be seized.ldquoThe only way to achieve lasting peace in Afghanistan is through a political solution.

title: joanna-cherry-dont-want-replace-nicola-want-get-know
story: This is an exclusive first look for our digital subscribers. More info HERECherry has announced her intention to seek her partyrsquos nomination to represent Edinburgh Central at next yearrsquos Holyrood election and Irsquom here to ask her why. After all, she has just been ed to Westminster where she increased her majority massively in Edinburgh South West. Why now  Is Westminster, the mother of all parliaments, not enough  Her main opponent from within the party will be Angus Robertson, another erudite child of this city.And yet, eloquent and fluent as they both are, this will be a bruising contest. Cherry and Robertson are two of the brightest and best in the party, but there seems no love lost between them. The contest hasnrsquot even started yet ndash the window for further nominations is still open ndash and Robertson has already had a swipe at his party colleague about empire-building. She has ed this with interest amidst disguised references to Robertsonrsquos carelessness in losing his Moray seat to a Tory in .A state of civil stre quietly thrums beneath the surface of this most disciplined of political machines, and Cherry and Robertson are seen to be on either side of the fault-line. Allies of Cherry feel Robertsonrsquos fingerprints are all over some of the moves that have been made against her within the Westminster group over the last year or so.Cherry, currently the MP for Edinburgh South West, has become one of the most recognised parliamentarians at Westminster since she won her seat in , feared and admired in equal measure. She was instrumental in defeating Boris Johnsonrsquos plan to sabotage parliament late last year and is a formidable speaker from the floor of the House. This has caused jealousy among lesser-plumed party colleagues who have dutully toiled in the party for years without any recognition. ldquoShersquos just in the door five minutes, they say, ldquoand already shersquos coveting Nicolarsquos job. Thatrsquos the real reason why she wants to run for Holyrood.ldquoSo, do you really want the First Ministerrsquos job, I ask her. Wersquore sitting in a tidy constituency office in Edinburghrsquos Jam Tarts district. Irsquove just told her thatshe wants to continue to do well here she should walk into the Tynecastle Arms and sing the famous old Hearts song: ldquoAye, Aye, Aye: Cruikshank is better than Yashin Busby is better than Eu-se-bio the Hibees are in for a thrashinrsquo. Irsquom hoping to catch her off-guard when I ask her the big Nicola Sturgeon question.:Scathing complaints accuse SNP MP Joanna Cherry of making party look regressiveldquoI donrsquot want to replace Nicola I want to get to know her better, she says. ldquoBut the pair of you can hardly stand to be in the same room as each other, I say. ldquoThatrsquos just idle speculation, she replies. ldquoNicola and I have so much in common we both studied law wersquore passionate feminists and passionate about reducing inequality.Another great week for #heraldonsunday. An indepth look at council cuts by @MartinWilliams  @mrdavidbol, fascinating interview with @joannaccherry by @kmckenna plus dont miss our fantastic new comment section. @heraldscotland #tomorrowspaperstoday #buyapaper pic GTaysxldquoWhenever Irsquom in other parts of the UK Irsquom told how much they admire Nicola and wish they could have someone as good as her in English politics. Irsquom proud of her and of how well shersquos represented the cause of Scottish independence. I want to support her in leading Scotland to independence and in securing ourto the European Union. I certainly have my dferences with her, not least on her support for the proposed reforms of the Gender recognition Act, but more unites us than ides us.Ah yes, the Gender Recognition Act: never has something so scarcelyunderstoodby the vast majority of the general population caused so much turbulence within the gilded chambers of a political party. For those who inhabit the world outside cyberspace and the political bubble this is what it means. The Scottish Government wants to make it much easier for people to change their gender by enabling them to "self-declare"rather than endure a prolonged process. Cherry and other feminists within the SNP, most notably Joan McAlpine, convenor of Holyroodrsquos influential Culture, Tourism, Europe and External Affairs Committee, have urged caution.Both women have endured abuse and intimidation from within the party for expressing concerns for womenrsquos sex-based rightsthe proposed GRA reforms come to pass. Cherry is careful to say that the abuse has come from ldquothe tiniest of factions who wield ldquodisproportionate influence.ldquoAs an out gay woman who fought section  and has campaigned for LGBT rights for decades, accusations that I am transphobic are offensive. The online abuse does take its toll but I am more worried about the cumulative and detrimental effect on what it does for the role of women in politics and in the media young women in particular. I donrsquot like the way this is characterised as a problem in the youth wing of the party.:MP Joanna Cherry: Scotland will be ignored at WestminsterldquoMany admirable young people are involved in Scottish politics and I know a number of women and men in Young Scots for Independence and SNP Youth who have spoken to me privately about their concerns. The abuse is deeply misogynistic. The attacks on me and other women in the party are clearly a breach of our code of conduct and must be dealt with.ldquoIrsquom very proud of the fact that in Scotland we have very good rights-based protections for trans people. No one is seeking to change that. However, women have legitimate concerns about the proposed changes to the law on gender recognition.Within the SNPrsquos Westminster group you sense she is admired rather than loved and therersquos not a little resentment at her high profile. One of her party colleagues at Holyrood has been aghast at her treatment at Westminster: ldquoShersquos a really sharp intellect, as forensic in her approach to politics as she was to the law. She does have what Burns called a guid conceit o hersel. This is admired and expected in male leaders, but women are held to a dferent standard and expected to show humility. She needs to build alliances though that is the clubby bit of politics which can evade hard-working women and allow mediocre men to advance.Cherry challenges my suggestion that the party could do without this contest in Edinburgh Central. ldquoCompetition in politics is healthy, she says. ldquoDebating ideas is good for developing policy. This isnrsquot being disloyal to the leadership. Holyrood and Westminster proceed by debate this is how we get to the nub of things.The fabled independence Plan B, which the party rejected last year, has ed for inspection now that Boris Johnson simply wonrsquot discuss a second independence referendum. This is another area where Cherry is perceived to be at odds with her boss. She rejects this.ldquoI wouldnrsquot back a wildcat or illegal referendum. How could I, given my legal background  I endorse Nicolarsquos declaration that this should proceed legally. However we have reached an impasse: people keep voting for us and opinion polls show support for Yes is hovering around %, yet Johnson wonrsquot budge.ldquoMy experience of knocking on doors is that there are lots of soft Nos who are interested in the idea of Scotland staying in the EU through independence. But we have to look at the economy and currency the process of getting back into the EU and how longrsquos it going to take. We must also deal with the border with England and de-dramatise it. The idea that people wonrsquot be able to have a cup of tea in Berwick without showing their passport is ludicrous. Wersquore all in the common travel area."Cherry is keen to stress that seeking a ruling from the Supreme Court on Holyroodrsquos competence to hold a referendum without Londonrsquos agreement does not amount to support for a wildcat vote."If we pass a bill through Holyrood to hold a referendum this might be challenged by the UK governmentrsquos law officer and then arrive at the Supreme Court. Any organisation could challenge it. Under section  of the Scotland Act within four weeks of a Bill passing the Advocate General, the Attorney General or the Scotlandrsquos Lord Advocate could choose to refer the question of the Billrsquos competence to the Supreme Court.ldquoIt would be for them to decide by a process of statutory interpretation whether this Bill was within the powers of Holyrood. Irsquod hope they wouldnrsquot just look at the Act but note the two countriesrsquo markedly dferent routes of travel and all the recent democratic votes in several political jurisdictions. If they said the Bill was within Holyroodrsquos competence wersquod have our referendum. Andnot I donrsquot think wersquod lose anything.Cherry would probably have been a judge by nowshersquod continued her legal career, with the prospect of earning much more money. She had a stellar career specialising in prosecuting sexual offence cases. Why did she choose this uncertain and venomous arena where party rules canrsquot prevent a woman from experiencing abuse and venom simply for adhering to long-held principles ldquoIf Irsquod known it would be like this I wouldnrsquot have stood for election, she says, ldquoand itrsquos sad that women might be put off entering politics because of it. And I donrsquot think Irsquove had the support I should have had through all of this.ldquoBut wersquore now at the end game for Scottish independence and the focus is on Holyrood. I want to be part of it. Independence for Scotland has been my lelong passion.

title: auld gits donation boost for foodbank
